text: I know <@U687RKK0E> likes it, but I've always thought that being able to define functions with lhs in infix syntax is too cute

text: How come it doesn't work for `startswith`?

elements.text: How come it doesn't work for

text: it requires an operator that is parsed as an infix symbol

elements.text: it requires an operator that is parsed as an infix symbol

text: allowing arbitrary functions to be used infix would complicate things quite a bit

elements.text: allowing arbitrary functions to be used infix would complicate things quite a bit

text: it suddenly makes your parser depend on the state of the program even more, which is non-ideal

elements.text: it suddenly makes your parser depend on the state of the program even more, which is non-ideal

text: I made a grammar and started working on prefix, infix, and postfix parsing. I won't explain how it works... But yea, writing a parser for it sucked. I mean yes it's a pratt parser, but then you have to have a user define explicit precedence, and it gets soupy fast. you end up having to recurse over global and local state and the surface area is spooky. Like closures, closures within closures within functions, macros, etc...

elements.text: I made a grammar and started working on prefix, infix, and postfix parsing. I won't explain how it works... But yea, writing a parser for it sucked. I mean yes it's a pratt parser, but then you have to have a user define explicit precedence, and it gets soupy fast. you end up having to recurse over global and local state and the surface area is spooky. Like closures, closures within closures within functions, macros, etc...

text: the way I see it, it's the ultimate sugar, but the cost is high, and getting it right is a nuisance for someone who doesn't write parsers regularly

elements.text: the way I see it, it's the ultimate sugar, but the cost is high, and getting it right is a nuisance for someone who doesn't write parsers regularly
